narrative.title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan
narrative.project_title: NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants

question.text: Types and amount of scientific data expected to be generated in the project

json.answer: The project titled 'NIH Data Management and Sharing Plan: Clinical and MRI Data from Human Research Participants' expects to generate a significant amount of demographic, clinical, and MRI-based imaging data. This includes tabular data for 220 participants (110 affected youth and 110 matched healthy controls) and multi-modal MRI imaging data such as structural MRI, fMRI, and 1H fMRS. The total volume of the dataset will depend on the specific imaging protocols used and the derivatives retained, with the imaging data expected to be the largest component.

question.text: Scientific data that will be preserved and shared, and the rationale for doing so

json.answer: All collected demographic, clinical, and MRI-based imaging data will be preserved and shared. The rationale for sharing these data is to facilitate transparency, reproducibility, and further research into the conditions under study. Sharing this comprehensive dataset will enable other researchers to explore new hypotheses, validate findings, and potentially discover novel biomarkers or therapeutic targets, thereby advancing our understanding of the affected conditions.

question.text: Metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation

json.answer:
To facilitate interpretation of the scientific data, the following metadata, other relevant data, and associated documentation will be made accessible: 
- Data dictionaries that describe the variables and their meanings within the demographic and clinical datasets.
- Study protocols outlining how the MRI imaging data were acquired, including details on machine settings and scan sequences used.
- README files providing an overview of the dataset structure, contents, and any specific instructions for use.
- Supporting documentation such as consent forms (with personal identifiers removed) to demonstrate compliance with ethical standards.

section.title: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

question.text: Element 2: Related Tools, Software and/or Code

json.answer:
Specialized tools, software, and/or code are needed to access or manipulate the shared scientific data. Specifically, for MRI imaging data:
- Software like FSL (FMRIB Software Library), AFNI (Analysis of Functional NeuroImages), or SPM (Statistical Parametric Mapping) will be necessary for analyzing fMRI and structural MRI data.
- For 1H fMRS data analysis, software such as LCModel or TARQUIN may be required.
These tools can typically be accessed through their respective websites or academic licenses, with detailed instructions provided in the accompanying documentation.

To enable interoperability of datasets and resources, common data standards will be applied to the scientific data and associated metadata. For demographic and clinical data:
- The use of standardized variable names and formats compliant with the National Institutes of Health (NIH) Data Dictionary is planned.
For MRI-based imaging data:
- Compliance with the Brain Imaging Data Structure (BIDS) standard for organizing and describing MRI datasets will be implemented to facilitate easy sharing and analysis of the imaging data.
These standards are widely recognized in their respective fields, ensuring that the generated data can be easily understood, combined, and further analyzed by other researchers.

section.title: Element 4: Data Preservation, Access, and Associated Timelines

question.text: Repository where scientific data and metadata will be archived

json.answer: The scientific data and metadata arising from this project will be archived in the NIMH Data Archive (NDA), a repository that supports the sharing of human subjects data in accordance with NIH policies. The NDA provides a secure, reliable, and accessible platform for storing and distributing sensitive research data.

question.text: How scientific data will be findable and identifiable

json.answer: The scientific data will be made findable and identifiable through the assignment of a persistent unique identifier (e.g., DOI - Digital Object Identifier) and inclusion in the NDA's searchable database. This allows researchers to easily locate, access, and cite specific datasets.

question.text: When and how long the scientific data will be made available

json.answer: The scientific data will be made available to other users no later than the time of an associated publication or the end of the performance period, whichever comes first. The data are expected to remain available for at least 10 years following the completion of the project to maximize their utility and impact on the research community.

section.title: Element 5: Access, Distribution, or Reuse Considerations

question.text: Factors affecting subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of scientific data

json.answer:
While maximizing data sharing is a priority, considerations related to informed consent, privacy, and confidentiality protections may affect subsequent access, distribution, or reuse of the scientific data. Specifically:
- All research participants will provide broad consent for data sharing, but certain sensitive information (e.g., personal identifiers) will be protected.
- De-identification processes will be applied to all shared datasets to prevent re-identification of human subjects.

question.text: Whether access to scientific data will be controlled

json.answer: Access to the scientific data will not be strictly controlled once they are deposited into the NDA, as the repository is designed for open sharing. However, users may need to register or agree to terms of use that respect the privacy and rights of the research participants.

question.text: Protections for privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants

json.answer:
To protect the privacy, rights, and confidentiality of human research participants:
- All data will be deidentified prior to sharing.
- A global unique identifier for the NIMH Data Archive (NDA) will be generated for each subject without revealing personal identifiers.
- The project will adhere to all relevant guidelines and regulations regarding human subjects research, including obtaining informed consent that explicitly includes provisions for broad data sharing.

section.title: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

question.text: Element 6: Oversight of Data Management and Sharing

json.answer: Compliance with this Data Management and Sharing Plan will be monitored and managed by the Principal Investigator (PI) in collaboration with the institution's data management office. Regular oversight meetings will be conducted quarterly to review progress, address any challenges or concerns related to data sharing, and ensure that all datasets are properly documented and prepared for deposition into the designated repository according to the outlined timelines. The PI and the data management team will also be responsible for ensuring that all project personnel are trained on the importance of data sharing, the procedures for deidentifying human subjects data, and the ethical considerations involved in managing and sharing sensitive research data.
